title: Wells Fargo repossessed our RV due to non-payment for the loan. they sold it and request the balance. what can they do?
question: what actions should we take (or not take) - we are not planning on making any payment since they took the vehicle and sold it. I know this situation will affect our credit, but exactly what damage can WF do at this time.
answers: What has been said is correct. However you may want to retain an attorney to defend you in this case. Their are various defenses that you may have.

If the RV sold for less than the balance due on your account, it is called a deficiency balance. A bank can sue you in court for that deficiency balance. Another attorney here suggested bankruptcy. Alternatively, it may be possible to negotiate a settlement for less than claimed due, depending on a number of factors. It may be best to have this discussion with an attorney that handles debt settlement and/or bankruptcy.
They are the damaged party. They can do as my colleagues have said. If you want to prevent that, you will have to file bankruptcy.
They can ultimately sue you in court, obtain a judgment, and then execute on the judgment. That means garnish wages, or attach and sell any significant assets you might have.

At "this time" not much. They can call you and send letters, and ding your credit. Eventually, they may sue you. If that happens and they obtain a judgment, then they can go after a wage garnishment, bank account levy and other assets as allowed by CA law.
